accessible-design-systems.author: Henny Swan
accessible-design-systems.title: Accessible design systems
accessible-design-systems.description: A design system is a library of styles, components, and patterns used by product teams to consistently and efficiently launch new pages and features. A good system has accessibility embedded throughout and includes documentation, guidelines and implementation notes for accessibility.

accessible-design-systems-dont-guarantee.author: Nathan Curtis
accessible-design-systems-dont-guarantee.title: “Accessible” Design Systems Don’t Guarantee Accessible Products
accessible-design-systems-dont-guarantee.description: Accessibility is an Adopter’s Job Too, and They’ve Got Work To Do.

adopting-design-systems.author: Nathan Curtis
adopting-design-systems.title: Adopting Design Systems
adopting-design-systems.description: A Playbook for Working with Product Teams & Managers

adopting-design-system-generations.author: Nathan Curtis
adopting-design-system-generations.title: Adopting Design System Generations
adopting-design-system-generations.description: How to face and reframe challenges of a changing system

design-tokens-naming-playbook.author: Romina Kavcic
design-tokens-naming-playbook.title: Design Tokens Naming Playbook
design-tokens-naming-playbook.description: So, what are design tokens? Design tokens are nicknames for design elements.

the-component-adoption-gap-understanding.author: Murphy Trueman
the-component-adoption-gap-understanding.title: The component adoption gap: Understanding the psychology behind design system success
the-component-adoption-gap-understanding.description: Why some elements become team favourites, while others gather digital dust –and what you can do about it.

usability-engineering.author: Jakob Nielsen
usability-engineering.title: Usability Engineering
usability-engineering.description: Foundational work on consistency as a usability principle focused on predictability rather than visual sameness.

about-face-the-essentials-of-interaction.author: Alan Cooper
about-face-the-essentials-of-interaction.title: About Face: The Essentials of Interaction Design
about-face-the-essentials-of-interaction.description: Explores consistency in interaction models and mental models, emphasizing meaning over appearance.

consistency-and-standards.author: Rachel Krause
consistency-and-standards.title: Consistency and Standards
consistency-and-standards.description: Clarifies that consistency is about reducing cognitive load, not visual duplication.

mobile-first.author: Luke Wroblewski
mobile-first.title: Mobile First
mobile-first.description: Demonstrates how context-driven variation is necessary while preserving consistent patterns.

styles-and-patterns.author: GOV.UK Design System
styles-and-patterns.title: Design your service using GOV.UK styles, components and patterns
styles-and-patterns.description: Real-world example of consistency through shared patterns rather than uniform components.

design-that-scales.author: Dan Mall
design-that-scales.title: Design That Scales
design-that-scales.description: In Design That Scales, design systems expert Dan Mall draws on his extensive experience helping some of the world’s most recognizable brands create design practices that are truly sustainable.

learning-javascript-design-patterns.author: Addy Osmani
learning-javascript-design-patterns.title: Learning JavaScript Design Patterns
learning-javascript-design-patterns.description: Connects implementation patterns to design intent.

architecting-subcomponents.author: Nathan Curtis
architecting-subcomponents.title: Architecting Subcomponents
architecting-subcomponents.description: Playing constant catch up, adding prop after prop to support and maintain too many cases? Break larger components into flexible subcomponents so that users can solve their unique problems themselves.

the-paradox-of-choice.author: Barry Schwartz
the-paradox-of-choice.title: The Paradox of Choice
the-paradox-of-choice.description: Shows how too many options hinder decision-making.

design-principles.author: Ben Brignell
design-principles.title: Design Principles
design-principles.description: An open source collection of Design Principles and methods.

the-culture-map.author: Erin Meyer
the-culture-map.title: The Culture Map
the-culture-map.description: Provides insight into decision-making and ownership across teams.

inspired.author: Marty Cagan
inspired.title: Inspired
inspired.description: Strong grounding in shipping usable solutions and iterating based on team and user feedback.

design-systems.author: Alla Kholmatova
design-systems.title: Design Systems
design-systems.description: Addresses why rigid, over-designed systems struggle with adoption in real organizations.

managing-design-systems-features-release.author: Nathan Curtis
managing-design-systems-features-release.title: Managing Design Systems: Features & Releases to Roadmaps & Backlogs
managing-design-systems-features-release.description: Making design system features is exciting. But what about managing assignments, tracking tasks, and discussing status? The momentum of emergent tokens and rapid Figma and code prototypes gives way to the dulling rigor of quality and collaboration across designers and developers wanting to operate independently.

gov-uk-community.author: GOV.UK Design System
gov-uk-community.title: Community
gov-uk-community.description: Demonstrates how imperfect systems evolve through use and contribution.

inclusive-design-patterns.author: Heydon Pickering
inclusive-design-patterns.title: Inclusive Design Patterns
inclusive-design-patterns.description: Practical guidance on building accessible UI patterns.

dont-make-me-think-revisited.author: Steve Krug
dont-make-me-think-revisited.title: Don't Make Me Think (Revisited)
dont-make-me-think-revisited.description: Highlights usability and accessibility as core quality attributes.

a-web-for-everyone.author: Sarah Horton & Whitney Quesenbery
a-web-for-everyone.title: A Web for Everyone
a-web-for-everyone.description: Explains inclusive design principles and accessibility foundations.

web-content-accessibility-guidelines-wca.author: W3C
web-content-accessibility-guidelines-wca.title: Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG)
web-content-accessibility-guidelines-wca.description: The global standard for accessible digital experiences.

accessibility-in-design-systems.author: GOV.UK
accessibility-in-design-systems.title: Accessibility in Design Systems
accessibility-in-design-systems.description: Shows how accessibility is treated as a baseline in a public-sector system.

accessibility-is-not-optional.author: NNGroup
accessibility-is-not-optional.title: Accessibility Is Not Optional
accessibility-is-not-optional.description: Explains why accessibility must be built into UX from the start.

the-design-of-everyday-things.author: Don Norman
the-design-of-everyday-things.title: The Design of Everyday Things
the-design-of-everyday-things.description: Explains how constraints guide user behavior and reduce error.

design-tokens-and-constraints.author: Material Design
design-tokens-and-constraints.title: Design Tokens and Constraints
design-tokens-and-constraints.description: Shows how constraints are encoded through tokens and system rules.

accessibility-constraints.author: GOV.UK Design System
accessibility-constraints.title: Accessibility Constraints
accessibility-constraints.description: Demonstrates non-negotiable constraints applied at system level.

scaling-up-design-systems.author: Randy Shoup
scaling-up-design-systems.title: Scaling Up Design Systems
scaling-up-design-systems.description: Practical insights on growing design systems across teams and products.

lightning-design-system-principles.author: Salesforce
lightning-design-system-principles.title: Lightning Design System: Principles
lightning-design-system-principles.description: Shows how scalable foundations support multiple products and teams.

sprint.author: Jake Knapp
sprint.title: Sprint
sprint.description: Shows how to quickly test ideas and gather feedback to make better decisions.

design-systems-need-feedback-loops.author: NNGroup
design-systems-need-feedback-loops.title: Design Systems Need Feedback Loops
design-systems-need-feedback-loops.description: Explains why feedback is critical for design system success.

semantic-versioning-specification.author: SemVer
semantic-versioning-specification.title: Semantic Versioning Specification
semantic-versioning-specification.description: Defines a clear contract for communicating breaking and non-breaking changes.

versioning-polaris.author: Shopify Engineering
versioning-polaris.title: Versioning Polaris
versioning-polaris.description: Describes how Shopify manages breaking changes in a large design system.

design-system-versioning-single-library-.author: Brad Frost
design-system-versioning-single-library-.title: Design system versioning: single library or individual components?
design-system-versioning-single-library-.description: This post breaks down the pros and cons of versioning the whole library vs individual components.

docs-like-code.author: Anne Gentle
docs-like-code.title: Docs Like Code
docs-like-code.description: Explains how documentation benefits from product thinking and engineering workflows.

documentation-guide.author: Write the Docs
documentation-guide.title: Documentation Guide
documentation-guide.description: Community-driven best practices for documentation as a product.

atomic-design.author: Brad Frost
atomic-design.title: Atomic Design
atomic-design.description: Introduces a compositional model for building scalable design systems.

modular-design-systems.author: Nathan Curtis
modular-design-systems.title: Modular Design Systems
modular-design-systems.description: Discusses ownership, authority, and the importance of a clear system boundary.

design-systems-for-developers.author: Storybook Team
design-systems-for-developers.title: Design Systems for Developers
design-systems-for-developers.description: Frames Storybook as infrastructure rather than presentation.

cognitive-load-and-ux.author: Aguayo
cognitive-load-and-ux.title: Cognitive Load and UX
cognitive-load-and-ux.description: Learn how cognitive load affects user experience and discover effective strategies to minimize it in your UX designs.

ease-cognitive-overload-in-ux-design.author: Mailchimp
ease-cognitive-overload-in-ux-design.title: Ease Cognitive Overload in UX Design
ease-cognitive-overload-in-ux-design.description: Learn how taxing working memory causes cognitive overload and ways to improve UX design for a better user experience.

design-consistency-guide-ui-and-ux-best-.author: UXPin
design-consistency-guide-ui-and-ux-best-.title: Design Consistency Guide UI and UX Best Practices
design-consistency-guide-ui-and-ux-best-.description: One of the key design principles, no matter if your designing a mobile app or a desktop one, is to keep your UI consistent. But what does it mean?

match-between-system-and-the-real-world.author: Meganne Ohata
match-between-system-and-the-real-world.title: Match Between System and Real World
match-between-system-and-the-real-world.description: The design should speak the users’ language. Use words, phrases, and concepts familiar to the user, rather than internal jargon. Follow real-world conventions, making information appear in a natural and logical order.

visibility-of-system-status-usability-he.author: Aurora Harley
visibility-of-system-status-usability-he.title: Visibility of System Status (Usability Heuristic #1)
visibility-of-system-status-usability-he.description: Communicating the current state allows users to feel in control of the system, take appropriate actions to reach their goal, and ultimately trust the brand.

match-between-system-and-real-world-usab.author: Anna Kaley
match-between-system-and-real-world-usab.title: Match Between the System and the Real World (Usability Heuristic #2)
match-between-system-and-real-world-usab.description: Systems should speak the users' language with familiar words, phrases, and concepts rather than system-oriented terms. Interfaces that follow real-world conventions and make information appear in a natural and logical order demonstrate empathy and acknowledgement for users.

user-control-and-freedom-usability-heuri.author: Maria Rosala
user-control-and-freedom-usability-heuri.title: User Control and Freedom (Usability Heuristic #3)
user-control-and-freedom-usability-heuri.description: Users often make mistakes or change their minds. Allow them to exit a flow or undo their last action and go back to the system’s previous state.

maintain-consistency-and-adhere-to-stand.author: Rachel Krause
maintain-consistency-and-adhere-to-stand.title: Maintain Consistency and Adhere to Standards (Usability Heuristic #4)
maintain-consistency-and-adhere-to-stand.description: Users should not have to wonder whether different words, situations, or actions mean the same thing. Follow platform and industry conventions.

error-prevention-usability-heuristic-5.author: Katie Sherwin
error-prevention-usability-heuristic-5.title: Usability Heuristic 5: Error Prevention
error-prevention-usability-heuristic-5.description: No. 5 of the top 10 UX design heuristics is to prevent interaction problems from occurring in the first place: either eliminate error-prone conditions or check for them and present users with a confirmation dialog.

flexibility-and-efficiency-of-use-usabil.author: Page Laubheimer
flexibility-and-efficiency-of-use-usabil.title: Flexibility and Efficiency of Use (Usability Heuristic #7)
flexibility-and-efficiency-of-use-usabil.description: Shortcuts — unseen by the novice user — speed up the interaction for the expert users such that the system can cater to both inexperienced and experienced users.

aesthetic-and-minimalist-design-usabilit.author: Therese Fessenden
aesthetic-and-minimalist-design-usabilit.title: Aesthetic and Minimalist Design (Usability Heuristic #8)
aesthetic-and-minimalist-design-usabilit.description: Aesthetically pleasing designs can provide memorable experiences that differentiate a brand. However, interfaces should only include necessary elements, with high informational value. Clarity will always win over visual flourish.

help-and-documentation-usability-heurist.author: Alita Kendrick
help-and-documentation-usability-heurist.title: Help and Documentation (Usability Heuristic #10)
help-and-documentation-usability-heurist.description: Interface help comes in two forms: proactive and reactive. Proactive help is intended to get users familiar with an interface while reactive help is meant for troubleshooting and gaining system proficiency.

10-usability-heuristics-for-user-interfa.author: Jakob Nielsen
10-usability-heuristics-for-user-interfa.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
10-usability-heuristics-for-user-interfa.description: Jakob Nielsen's 10 general principles for interaction design. They are called "heuristics" because they are broad rules of thumb and not specific usability guidelines.

recognition-rather-than-recall-simplifie.author: Harsh Gorasia
recognition-rather-than-recall-simplifie.title: Heuristics #6: Recognition Rather Than Recall-Simplified by the examples.
recognition-rather-than-recall-simplifie.description: The Jakob Nielsen’s 10 heuristics will be served as a series or as episodes to you all. I will publish each heuristic a week- Every Thursday.

jakob-nielsens-sixth-usability-heuristic.author: Melissa Vela
jakob-nielsens-sixth-usability-heuristic.title: Jakob Nielsen’s sixth usability heuristic for user interface design
jakob-nielsens-sixth-usability-heuristic.description: Designers rely on heuristic evaluations to improve upon product usability. This article will focus on the sixth principle of Jakob Nielsen’s 10 general principles for interaction design which is Recognition Rather than Recall.

the-psychology-of-default-options-in-use.author: Erik Fiala
the-psychology-of-default-options-in-use.title: The Psychology of Default Options in User Interfaces
the-psychology-of-default-options-in-use.description: Default options play a crucial role in user interface (UI) design, significantly influencing user behavior and decision-making processes.

personas-make-users-memorable.author: Taylor Dykes
personas-make-users-memorable.title: Personas Make Users Memorable
personas-make-users-memorable.description: Personas support user-centered design throughout a project’s lifecycle by making user groups feel real and tangible.

experience-design-the-next-iteration-of-.author: Kate Moran
experience-design-the-next-iteration-of-.title: Experience Design: The Next Iteration of UX?
experience-design-the-next-iteration-of-.description: As an umbrella term for UX/CX work, “experience design” reflects blended roles and core human-centered principles.

no-one-likes-making-errors.author: Nielsen Norman Group
no-one-likes-making-errors.title: No one likes making errors
no-one-likes-making-errors.description: Even if they are mistakes, they can make you feel flustered, ashamed, or just be plain annoying.

error-message-guidelines.author: Tim Neusesser, Evan Sunwall
error-message-guidelines.title: Error-Message Guidelines
error-message-guidelines.description: Design effective error messages by ensuring they are highly visible, provide constructive communication, and respect user effort.

designing-better-error-messages-ux.author: Vitaly Friedman
designing-better-error-messages-ux.title: Designing Better Error Messages UX
designing-better-error-messages-ux.description: Error messages need to be easy to spot, but they also need to be helpful. Let’s explore when error messages should live above input fields and why toast error messages are usually not a very good idea.

good-defaults-in-ux-design-ux-knowledge-.author: Krisztina Szerovay
good-defaults-in-ux-design-ux-knowledge-.title: Good Defaults in UX design — UX Knowledge Piece Sketch #39
good-defaults-in-ux-design-ux-knowledge-.description: A default is a ready-made decision for your users. You preselect values, settings or preferences for the user. As a result, you can avoid decision fatigue and reduce cognitive load.

progressive-disclosure-in-ux-design-type.author: Eric Chung
progressive-disclosure-in-ux-design-type.title: Progressive disclosure in UX design: Types and use cases
progressive-disclosure-in-ux-design-type.description: Progressive disclosure is a UX design technique that reduces users’ cognitive load by gradually revealing information as needed. It’s commonly used in product design to simplify complex content or break down large amounts of information into digestible bits.

scaling-design-impact-why-growing-compan.author: Shivangi Sharma
scaling-design-impact-why-growing-compan.title: Scaling Design Impact
scaling-design-impact-why-growing-compan.description: Why Growing Companies Need Dedicated UX/UI Expertise to Maintain Momentum.

why-ux-design-consistency-matters-and-ho.author: Agustin Diaz
why-ux-design-consistency-matters-and-ho.title: Why UX design consistency matters and how to achieve it
why-ux-design-consistency-matters-and-ho.description: Consistency in UX design isn't about making everything look the same. It's about creating harmony that helps users feel at home.

design-system-coerenza-atomica.author: Damiano Dalla Lana
design-system-coerenza-atomica.title: DESIGN SYSTEM: COERENZA “ATOMICA”
design-system-coerenza-atomica.description: Come riutilizzare elementi autonomi per creare progetti scalabili.

design-principles-for-reducing-cognitive.author: Jon Yablonski
design-principles-for-reducing-cognitive.title: Design Principles for Reducing Cognitive Load
design-principles-for-reducing-cognitive.description: Every time you visit a website, a process of learning is initiated in the brain.

user-centered-design-4-key-principles-ph.author: Armin Tanovic, Lorelei Whitman
user-centered-design-4-key-principles-ph.title: User-centered design: 4 key principles, phases, and examples
user-centered-design-4-key-principles-ph.description: The best products are shaped by the people who use them—user-centered design places them at the heart of your design process.

what-is-user-centered-design-ucd.author: Interaction Design Foundation
what-is-user-centered-design-ucd.title: What is User Centered Design (UCD)?
what-is-user-centered-design-ucd.description: User-centered design (UCD) is an iterative design process in which designers focus on the users and their needs in each phase of the design process.

5-principles-of-visual-design-in-ux.author: Kelley Gordon
5-principles-of-visual-design-in-ux.title: 5 Principles of Visual Design in UX
5-principles-of-visual-design-in-ux.description: The principles of scale, visual hierarchy, balance, contrast, and Gestalt not only create beautiful designs, but also increase usability when applied correctly.

effective-practices-on-preventing-errors.author: Tubik
effective-practices-on-preventing-errors.title: Effective Practices on Preventing Errors in User Interfaces
effective-practices-on-preventing-errors.description: No doubt, the best mistake is the one that wasn’t made. However, life isn’t like that, and user experience as well: mistakes are an integral part of both.

how-designers-can-prevent-user-errors.author: Jordan Bowman
how-designers-can-prevent-user-errors.title: How Designers Can Prevent User Errors
how-designers-can-prevent-user-errors.description: The term “user error” implies that it’s the user’s fault when they do something wrong. But in the vast majority of cases, the fault actually rests with the designer for having created an interface that is confusing or makes it too easy for the user to make a mistake.

why-visual-hierarchy-in-ux-is-key-expert.author: Stan Murash
why-visual-hierarchy-in-ux-is-key-expert.title: Why Visual Hierarchy in UX Is Key: Expert-Backed Tips and Examples
why-visual-hierarchy-in-ux-is-key-expert.description: What makes a design look messy and unprofessional? More often than not, it's a lack of visual hierarchy—a structured way to guide the user’s eye through an interface.
